intro: Sagina anomala, commonly known as common sandwort, is a low-growing perennial plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It belongs to the family Montiaceae and is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit. The plant features small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically pink or white, arranged in clusters near the base of the leaves. Its leaves are usually narrow and fleshy, adapted to retain moisture in dry environments. Sagina anomala thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in alpine or coastal regions.
